clusters.title: Care Quality Commission chief quits over maternity inquiry into NHS trust he led
clusters.neutral_headline: Care Quality Commission chief quits over maternity inquiry into NHS trust he led: Julian Hartley says his role at CQC ‘incompatible’ with investigation into Leeds trust he headed for 10 yearsThe chief executive of the Care Quality Commission has quit after the announcement of an independent inquiry into maternity failings at an NHS trust he led for a decade.Sir Julian Hartley said staying in his current role was “incompatible” with the investigation into Leeds teaching hospitals NHS trust (LTH), which he led for 10 years until 2023, and said it could “undermine trust and confidence in the regulator”. Continue reading

He felt his CQC role was incompatible with the inquiry.
The resignation aims to maintain trust in the regulator.

clusters.title: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’
clusters.neutral_headline: Americans brace for food stamps to run out: ‘The greatest hunger catastrophe since the Great Depression’: Nearly 42 million people in danger as federal government shutdown continues and Snap funding to end 1 NovemberUS politics – follow liveTwo decades ago, Sara Carlson, then a mother of three, was newly single because of a traumatic event, and the US’s food stamp program, now called the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), helped her feed her children with free food supplies.“I wouldn’t have been able to afford to live,” said Carlson, 45, who lives in Rochester, Minnesota, and now works as an operations manager for a wealth-management firm and serves on the board of Channel One Regional Food Bank, which works to increase food access. Continue reading

Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly 42 million people in danger as federal government shutdown continues and Snap funding to end 1 NovemberUS politics – follow liveTwo decades ago, Sara Carlson, then a mother of three, was newly single because of a traumatic event, and the US’s food stamp program, now called the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), helped her feed her children with free food supplies.“I wouldn’t have been able to afford to live,” said Carlson, 45, who lives in Rochester, Minnesota, and now works as an operations manager for a wealth-management firm and serves on the board of Channel One Regional Food Bank, which works to increase food access. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Americans face potential food stamp shortages.
Nearly 42 million people are at risk.
The federal government shutdown is a contributing factor.
SNAP funding is set to end on November 1st.
The situation is described as a potential hunger crisis.

clusters.title: Surgeons remove up to 100 magnets from New Zealand teenager’s intestines
clusters.neutral_headline: Teenager Swallows Magnets, Requires Intestinal Surgery

items.title: Surgeons remove up to 100 magnets from New Zealand teenager’s intestines
items.standfirst: Boy, 13, swallowed the high-power magnets after apparently buying them from the online retailer TemuA 13-year-old boy in New Zealand swallowed up to 100 high-power magnets he bought online, forcing surgeons to remove tissue from his intestines, doctors said on Friday.After suffering four days of abdominal pain, the unnamed teenager was taken to Tauranga hospital in the North Island. “He disclosed ingesting approximately 80 to 100 5x2mm high-power (neodymium) magnets about one week prior,” said a report by hospital doctors in the New Zealand Medical Journal.This article’s byline was amended on 25 October 2025 to correct the news agency it was attributed to. An earlier version incorrectly attributed it to Associated Foreign Press; however the correct agency was Agence France-Presse. Continue reading...
items.content: Boy, 13, swallowed the high-power magnets after apparently buying them from the online retailer TemuA 13-year-old boy in New Zealand swallowed up to 100 high-power magnets he bought online, forcing surgeons to remove tissue from his intestines, doctors said on Friday.After suffering four days of abdominal pain, the unnamed teenager was taken to Tauranga hospital in the North Island. “He disclosed ingesting approximately 80 to 100 5x2mm high-power (neodymium) magnets about one week prior,” said a report by hospital doctors in the New Zealand Medical Journal.This article’s byline was amended on 25 October 2025 to correct the news agency it was attributed to. An earlier version incorrectly attributed it to Associated Foreign Press; however the correct agency was Agence France-Presse. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A thirteen-year-old boy in New Zealand swallowed approximately 80 to 100 magnets.
The boy purchased the high-power magnets online from the retailer Temu.
He experienced abdominal pain for four days before being taken to a hospital.
Surgeons removed tissue from his intestines due to the ingested magnets.
The report was published in the New Zealand Medical Journal.

clusters.title: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Scientists Demand Cancer Warnings on Bacon, Ham

items.title: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK
items.standfirst: Successive governments criticised for doing ‘virtually nothing’ to reduce risk in decade since cancer link foundBacon and ham sold in the UK should carry cigarette-style labels warning that chemicals in them cause bowel cancer, scientists say.Their demand comes as they criticise successive British governments for doing “virtually nothing” to reduce the risk from nitrites in the decade since they were found to definitely cause cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: Successive governments criticised for doing ‘virtually nothing’ to reduce risk in decade since cancer link foundBacon and ham sold in the UK should carry cigarette-style labels warning that chemicals in them cause bowel cancer, scientists say.Their demand comes as they criticise successive British governments for doing “virtually nothing” to reduce the risk from nitrites in the decade since they were found to definitely cause cancer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Scientists want cigarette-style labels on bacon and ham in the UK.
These labels would warn about cancer-causing chemicals in the products.
The scientists criticize the government for inaction on cancer risk.
They cite the decade since nitrites were found to cause cancer.
The scientists believe the government has done virtually nothing to reduce risk.

clusters.title: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure
clusters.neutral_headline: Study Reveals Difficulty Avoiding Pesticide Exposure

items.title: ‘I was contaminated’: study reveals how hard it is to avoid pesticide exposure
items.standfirst: Silicone wristbands worn by volunteers in the Netherlands captured 173 substances in one weekFor decades, Khoji Wesselius has noticed the oily scent of pesticides during spraying periods when the wind has blown through his tiny farming village in a rural corner of the Netherlands.Now, after volunteering in an experiment to count how many such substances people are subjected to, Wesselius and his wife are one step closer to understanding the consequences of living among chemical-sprayed fields of seed potato, sugar beet, wheat, rye and onion. Continue reading...
items.content: Silicone wristbands worn by volunteers in the Netherlands captured 173 substances in one weekFor decades, Khoji Wesselius has noticed the oily scent of pesticides during spraying periods when the wind has blown through his tiny farming village in a rural corner of the Netherlands.Now, after volunteering in an experiment to count how many such substances people are subjected to, Wesselius and his wife are one step closer to understanding the consequences of living among chemical-sprayed fields of seed potato, sugar beet, wheat, rye and onion. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Volunteers wore silicone wristbands to measure pesticide exposure.
The wristbands captured 173 substances in one week.
Khoji Wesselius noticed the scent of pesticides in his village.
He lives near fields sprayed with pesticides.
The study aims to understand the consequences of pesticide exposure.

clusters.title: Drax faces lawsuits over claims workers developed asthma from wood dust
clusters.neutral_headline: Drax Faces Lawsuits Over Worker Asthma Claims

items.title: Drax faces lawsuits over claims workers developed asthma from wood dust
items.standfirst: Current and former employees say they were not adequately protected despite knowledge of health risksTen lawsuits have been filed against Drax after diagnoses of asthma allegedly linked to its wood pellet fuel, it has been revealed.Current and former workers at the UK’s largest power station claim they have not been adequately protected against sustained exposure to wood dust, which can cause serious health problems including asthma, dermatitis and nasal cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: Current and former employees say they were not adequately protected despite knowledge of health risksTen lawsuits have been filed against Drax after diagnoses of asthma allegedly linked to its wood pellet fuel, it has been revealed.Current and former workers at the UK’s largest power station claim they have not been adequately protected against sustained exposure to wood dust, which can cause serious health problems including asthma, dermatitis and nasal cancer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ten lawsuits have been filed against Drax power station.
The lawsuits allege workers developed asthma from wood dust exposure.
Current and former employees claim inadequate protection.
Wood dust exposure can cause asthma, dermatitis, and nasal cancer.
Drax is the UK's largest power station.

clusters.title: Prostate cancer drug that can halve death risk to be offered to thousands in England
clusters.neutral_headline: Prostate cancer drug that can halve death risk to be offered to thousands in England

items.title: Prostate cancer drug that can halve death risk to be offered to thousands in England
items.standfirst: At least 6,000 men a year with hormone-sensitive cancer to get access to darolutamide, which blocks growth with fewer side-effectsThousands of men with advanced prostate cancer in England are to be offered a drug that can halve the risk of death.In guidance published on Friday, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) gave the green light to darolutamide, which attacks the disease by starving cancer cells and has fewer side-effects than existing treatments. Continue reading...
items.content: At least 6,000 men a year with hormone-sensitive cancer to get access to darolutamide, which blocks growth with fewer side-effectsThousands of men with advanced prostate cancer in England are to be offered a drug that can halve the risk of death.In guidance published on Friday, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) gave the green light to darolutamide, which attacks the disease by starving cancer cells and has fewer side-effects than existing treatments. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Thousands of men in England will receive darolutamide.
Darolutamide can halve the risk of death from prostate cancer.
The drug is for men with hormone-sensitive cancer.
NICE approved darolutamide for use.
The drug has fewer side effects than existing treatments.

items.title: Resident doctors in England to go on strike for five days next month
items.standfirst: Hospital bosses warn 14-19 November stoppage will make it harder to manage winter viruses and tackle waiting lists Resident doctors in England will strike again next month – the 13th time since 2023 – a decision NHS bosses say is “the last thing the NHS needs”.Hospital chiefs predicted that the stoppage would make it harder for the NHS to manage the increase in winter viruses and hamper its efforts to tackle the 7.4m waiting list backlog. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Resident doctors in England will strike for five days.
The strike is the 13th since 2023.

The strike will make managing winter viruses harder.
It will also hamper efforts to tackle waiting lists.

clusters.title: After centuries of trauma, Montana’s Blackfeet Nation turns to an old friend for food sovereignty: bison
clusters.neutral_headline: Blackfeet Nation Revives Bison for Food Sovereignty in Montana

items.title: After centuries of trauma, Montana’s Blackfeet Nation turns to an old friend for food sovereignty: bison
items.standfirst: Local non-profits and schools are helping students explore traditional practices paired with modern science to make food sovereignty a realityThe Blackfeet Nation is a remote and rugged landscape on the windswept plains of northern Montana. While rich in resources, the remote location and management by the federal government have made food access a challenge here.Only four grocery stores serve the entire reservation. Fresh, healthy produce and meat options are often limited at these stores, and prices are higher than in neighboring communities, making access difficult for low–income families. Instead, highly processed foods, rich in sugars, carbohydrates and fat make up the bulk of the food choices. Continue reading...
items.content: Local non-profits and schools are helping students explore traditional practices paired with modern science to make food sovereignty a realityThe Blackfeet Nation is a remote and rugged landscape on the windswept plains of northern Montana. While rich in resources, the remote location and management by the federal government have made food access a challenge here.Only four grocery stores serve the entire reservation. Fresh, healthy produce and meat options are often limited at these stores, and prices are higher than in neighboring communities, making access difficult for low–income families. Instead, highly processed foods, rich in sugars, carbohydrates and fat make up the bulk of the food choices. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Blackfeet Nation in Montana faces food access challenges due to remoteness and limited grocery options.
Only four grocery stores serve the reservation, with higher prices and limited fresh food availability.
Highly processed foods dominate the food choices, impacting the health of low-income families.
Local initiatives and schools are teaching traditional practices and modern science to students.
The Blackfeet Nation is working to achieve food sovereignty by reintroducing bison.
